page.title: 07LOCAL HISTORY - DRUM CASTLE
page.content: Drum Castle was in the possession of one family, the Irvines, for 653 years until 1964 when the then laird bequeathed it to the National Trust for Scotland. Drum Park - from the Gaelic 'druim' meaning a ridge - was bestowed upon William de Irwin of Woodhouse, by King Robert Bruce, for his loyalty as secretary and armour bearer. The Tower was built around 1286,strategically overlooking an ancient drove road and the fords of the River Dee. The Jacobean House,built in 1619 has many family portraits,while the roof of the Library is decorated by heraldic shields of family connections of the wives. The Chapel contains a silver figure of the Blessed Virgin from Augsburg. The Castle opened to the public in 1976.
